results.title: Mother infant interaction: forms of feeding at six weeks
results.creator_credit: Sylvia Brody, New York Infant Development Project and Film-Rite
results.brief_description: This film shows over one hundred infants and their mothers who were studied to try and work out a pattern of behaviour during the baby’s feeding. Seven types were noticed within the schema of empathy, control and efficiency. Those mothers who showed positive signs of all of these did best. Many mothers showed little sensitivity to the needs of their babies and this was still obvious a year later.

results.title: Mother hen's family
results.brief_description: A young boy’s observations of the development of a chick embryo are used to introduce elementary concepts of reproduction and growth. Shows growth and development of a living embryo, hatching of egg and growth of young chicken.

results.title: Mother Goose rhymes: background for reading and expression
results.brief_description: Brings to life, in “Mother Goose Land”, a host of nursery favourites: Little Bo-Peep, London Bridge, Jack-Be-Nimble, The Old Woman who lived in a Shoe and others. Designed as a stimulus for junior grades, in reading and expression.

results.title: Mother earth, father sky
results.creator_credit: John Holmstrom and Ford Motor Company
results.brief_description: Years ago all America was the outdoors but only the Indians understood the true beauty of it all. As immigrants built roads, the meaning of the outdoors changed and became more accessible. Now outdoor enjoyment tends to be more organised, but whether it is bike riding in Central Park in New York or walking in the Grand Canyon, all interests can be catered for. “By being outdoors we all gain a special look at ourselves through Nature”.

results.title: Mother earth
results.creator_credit: L. Scott-Ehrenberg, Charles Blanks and Rural Bank of New South Wales
results.brief_description: Diary of Brian Gordon. Brian Gordon and his younger brother Michael, Sydneysiders, embark on a trip to rural New South Wales. Taken by the peace and lifestyle of the farming districts, both regret their imminent return to the city. But as luck would have it, Brian meets and falls in love with an orphaned country girl, Marian. Fortunately Brian is able to arrange a Rural Bank of New South Wales loan to assist himself and the cash-strapped Marian save her farm. A patriotic and heroic view of the idealised bush of a by-gone era. NB: A promotional film for the Rural Bank of New South Wales.

results.title: Mother Courage
results.material_description: video, monitor, van, mixed media props, paintings, colour and sound
results.brief_description: Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

constellations_other.name: Warwick Thornton
constellations_other.description: Brimming with Shakespearean undertones and pathos, Kaytetye filmmaker Warwick Thornton's debut feature Samson and Delilah is both a universal tale and one intrinsically tied to the experience of First Peoples in Central Australia.

results.description:
Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

“The installation comprises a white van housing a dual screen projection of an elderly Aboriginal woman artist and her grandson. Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.
‘Mother Courage’ is inspired by Bertolt Brecht’s famous character Mother Courage. In Brecht’s 1939 play, ‘Mother Courage and her Children’, the title character, displaced by war, survives by moving and adapting to whatever life throws at her. In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.
Thornton’s ‘Mother Courage’ was first exhibited in 2012 at the prestigious contemporary art exhibition dOCUMENTA (13) held in Kassel, Germany. For the period of the exhibition, it was constantly on the move, ‘parked outside the most prestigious galleries in town, for art aficionados to peer in its grimy windows through its rear doors, to wonder at the business inside’. At ACMI, the work was reborn within the space of Gallery 2, no longer on the move, but cutting against the grain of the white cube/black box experience of the art gallery space.” [Source: ACMI Education resource kit]
description_for_label:

Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.

In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.

results.title: Mother cat and her baby skunks
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A mother cat finds three baby skunks in the woods that have lost their mother. She adopts them and induces them to return to the farmyard where she has three kittens of her own. The baby skunks and kittens are shown developing side by side. The farm dog lives in harmony with the cat and helps her to protect the babies.
